newsitem.title: USA: US spot resids steady to up, NYH gains on weather.
newsitem.headline: US spot resids steady to up, NYH gains on weather.

text.p: U.S. spot fuel oil prices were steady to up again Thursday in moderate activity, with a stifling heat wave still propping up New York Harbor values, while grades at the Gulf Coast held relatively steady.

"Consumption on the East Coast is really moving, so prices should get stronger near-term," said one East Coast trader, noting power demand today hit a record again in New England and was at near-record levels all along the East Coast.
With oil units cranking this week to meet the unexpected surge in demand, most agreed utilities would soon be forced back into the market to replenish supplies.
While cooler East Coast temperatures are expected for the weekend, a return to slightly above-normal weather was forecast for early next week.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent edged 15 cents higher to the low-$17 a barrel area, with August one percent paper up a quarter to $16.75-17.00 with firmer crude.

There was no word on a New York utility tender for two cargoes of one percent for delivery by 7/30-8/4 and 8/6-10. NYH 0.3 percent high pour also was up slightly to $18.00-25 on prospects for better utility demand after the recent heat wave.
High sulphurs in New York also were modestly higher, with 2.2 percent now talked at $15.25-50.
At the U.S. Gulf, prices were stable, with one percent still in the low-$16s and three percent at $14.50-75.
No NYH or USG deals were reported.

New York city gate swing gas Thursday again firmed a couple of cents to about the $2.60/mmBtu level, or $16.38 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, jumped five cents to $2.28/mmBtu, or $14.36 a barrel, on storm hype in the U.S. Gulf.
